title: Federal election 2025 live updates: Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton campaign in final week before Australia votes – latest news
snippets:
Former prime minister says Coalition leader’s comments will turn a lot of voters off. Follow today’s news live

  • Anywhere but Canberra: Australian voters on what matters to them
  • Polls tracker; Election guide; Interactive seat explorer
  • Party policies; Micro parties explained; Full election coverage
  • Listen to the latest episode of our new narrative podcast series: Gina
  • Get our afternoon election email,free app or daily news podcast

Coalition’s policy costings to come ‘in the next couple of days’, Taylor says

While Labor’s costings are warm off the press (released yesterday afternoon), the Coalition are still waiting to put out their numbers on how they’ll pay for all of their promises.

You will see them in the next couple of days … and the sneak preview is you will see a stronger budget position from Labor’s costings yesterday.

He rang me. He said, “Hi Adam, it’s Tony Abbott here. I’ve always considered myself a bit of an environmentalist. I think we should talk.”

A very short conversation. A very short conversation and Peter Dutton would get the same response this time.

Everyone says they’re not going to talk but I would be astounded if they refused to respect the parliament that the Australian people select. The flipside of that is that we’ve all got to give a bit.

Continue reading...

summary: A former Australian prime minister criticized the Coalition leader's remarks, suggesting they could alienate voters. Meanwhile, the Coalition is set to release its policy costings in the coming days, aiming to present a stronger budget position than Labor, which has already published its financial plans. The dialogue underscores the competitive atmosphere leading up to the federal election, with both major parties vying to showcase their fiscal responsibility and appeal to the electorate.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into the strategies of major political parties in the run-up to the Australian federal election, offering readers a deeper understanding of the political landscape. However, it does not report on solutions, improvements or innovations, nor does it significantly increase clarity around systems, causes, trends, or impacts.

title: ‘Pure culture-war stuff’: Turnbull and Wyatt criticise Dutton’s welcome to country comments
snippets:
First Indigenous Australian to serve as federal minister says ‘to politicise it just adds to the division’

  • Election 2025 live updates: Australia federal election campaign
  • Get our afternoon election email, free app or daily news podcast

Former Liberal prime minister Malcolm Turnbull has dismissed Peter Dutton’s concerns about acknowledgement of country as “pure culture-war stuff” that will cost votes, hours after Australia’s first Indigenous minister warned the opposition leader’s comments were damaging social harmony.

Ken Wyatt, a former Liberal minister and the first Indigenous minister for Indigenous Australians, said he was disappointed by some of the commentary about an alleged overuse of the ceremonies and told politicians to “stay out of it”.

Sign up for the Afternoon Update: Election 2025 email newsletter

Continue reading...
titles: ‘Pure culture-war stuff’: Turnbull and Wyatt criticise Dutton’s welcome to country comments
summary: Ken Wyatt, the first Indigenous Australian to serve as a federal minister, criticized the politicization of "acknowledgement of country" ceremonies, stating it exacerbates division. This came after former Liberal Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull labeled opposition leader Peter Dutton's concerns over the ceremonies as "culture-war stuff" likely to lose votes. Wyatt, disappointed by the commentary suggesting an overuse of these ceremonies, advised politicians to refrain from involvement, emphasizing the negative impact on social harmony.
constructiveness_reason: This story offers some useful context about the political debate surrounding 'acknowledgement of country' ceremonies in Australia. It also raises awareness about the potential negative impacts of politicizing such ceremonies. However, it does not provide actionable insights or report on solutions to the issue.

title: Canada election 2025 live: Mark Carney says ‘Trump is trying to break us’ after Liberal win
snippets:
Prime minister tells Canadians that America ‘wants our land, our resources, our water’ and promises to protect country

  • Mark Carney’s Liberal party wins fourth term
  • Analysis: Carney owes much to luck … and Trump
  • Canada election 2025: full results

A record number of people – 7.3 million – have already voted during an early voting period that was held last weekend. That topped the 5.8 million Canadians who voted early at the last federal election in 2021.

All ballots in a Canadian federal election are counted by hand in front of witnesses, and the final results are validated over a period of time then made available online.

titles: Canada election 2025 live: Mark Carney says ‘Trump is trying to break us’ after Liberal win
Canada election 2025 live: Mark Carney says ‘Trump is trying to break us’ after Liberal win
summary: Mark Carney's Liberal party secured a fourth term in Canada's 2025 federal election, amid statements from the Prime Minister about protecting Canada from American desires for its land, resources, and water. A record 7.3 million Canadians voted early, surpassing the 5.8 million early votes in the 2021 election. All Canadian federal election ballots are manually counted in the presence of witnesses, with final results being validated and published online over time.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the Canadian federal election, including the increase in early voting and the process of counting and validating votes. These details offer readers a deeper understanding of the electoral system. However, the story does not highlight progress or solutions, and the comment about Trump's intentions could be seen as sensational, reducing the overall constructive score.

title: UCLA Tests Wearable “Brain Booster” for Hard-To-Treat ADHD Cases
snippets: Noninvasive therapy seeks to enhance focus and behavior by gently stimulating a nerve associated with attention and executive functioning. Researchers at UCLA Health are initiating the first clinical trial to determine whether a wearable device that provides gentle nerve stimulation during sleep can help reduce ADHD symptoms in children who were exposed to alcohol before [...]
titles: UCLA Tests Wearable “Brain Booster” for Hard-To-Treat ADHD Cases
summary: UCLA Health is conducting the first clinical trial to test a wearable device designed to alleviate ADHD symptoms in children exposed to alcohol prenatally. This noninvasive therapy aims to improve focus and behavior by stimulating a nerve linked to attention and executive functioning during sleep.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it reports on an innovative solution to a persistent problem (ADHD in children exposed to alcohol prenatally). It provides useful information about a new, noninvasive therapy, and increases awareness about ongoing research in the field.

title: Printing the Future of Life: How 3D Collagen Scaffolds Grow Real Tissues
snippets: Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh have created a groundbreaking tissue engineering platform using 3D-printed collagen scaffolds called CHIPS. By mimicking natural cellular environments, they enable cells to grow, interact, and form functional tissues — a major step beyond traditional silicone-based microfluidic models. The platform not only models diseases like diabetes but could also replace [...]
titles: Printing the Future of Life: How 3D Collagen Scaffolds Grow Real Tissues
summary: Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh have developed a new tissue engineering platform using 3D-printed collagen scaffolds, known as CHIPS. This innovation allows cells to grow and interact in a way that mimics their natural environment, forming functional tissues. This method represents a significant advancement over older silicone-based microfluidic models, with potential applications in disease modeling and tissue replacement, including for conditions like diabetes.
constructiveness_reason: This story is very constructive as it highlights a significant innovation in tissue engineering. It offers readers a deeper understanding of how this new technology works and its potential applications in disease modeling and tissue replacement. It also discusses the progress made over older methods, providing context and insight.

title: New Molecule Supercharges Perovskite Solar Cells for Higher Efficiency and Stability
snippets: KAUST is part of an international collaboration that has demonstrated how an ionic salt molecule, known as CPMAC, can significantly boost solar cell performance by 0.6%. A new study published in Science reveals that integrating a synthetic molecule significantly improves the energy efficiency and lifespan of perovskite solar cells. The molecule, called CPMAC, was developed [...]
titles: New Molecule Supercharges Perovskite Solar Cells for Higher Efficiency and Stability
summary: An international team, including researchers from KAUST, has developed a synthetic molecule named CPMAC that can enhance the efficiency of perovskite solar cells by 0.6%. The study, published in Science, shows that CPMAC not only increases the energy efficiency but also extends the lifespan of these solar cells. This advancement marks a significant step forward in solar technology, promising more durable and efficient solar energy solutions.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it reports on an advancement in solar technology that enhances the efficiency and lifespan of perovskite solar cells. It provides useful information about the new synthetic molecule and its impact on solar energy solutions. The story increases awareness about the ongoing efforts to improve renewable energy sources.

title: Today’s AI Risks Are Scarier Than Doomsday Predictions, Study Finds
snippets: A new University of Zurich study shows that people are more concerned about the immediate risks of AI, like bias and misinformation, than about distant existential threats. Most people are more concerned about the immediate risks of artificial intelligence than about distant, theoretical threats to humanity’s survival. A new study from the University of Zurich [...]
titles: Today’s AI Risks Are Scarier Than Doomsday Predictions, Study Finds
summary: A University of Zurich study found that people are more worried about immediate AI risks such as bias and misinformation rather than distant existential threats. This indicates a shift in public concern towards the practical, short-term impacts of artificial intelligence on society.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into public perceptions of AI and its potential risks, contributing to a deeper understanding of societal attitudes. However, it does not offer solutions or progress towards addressing these concerns.

title: Ghost Highways in Memory Chips – The Secret Electron Shortcut to Lightning-Fast AI
snippets: A major breakthrough at POSTECH could dramatically boost AI speeds and device efficiency. Researchers have, for the first time, decoded how Electrochemical Random-Access Memory (ECRAM) works, using a special technique to observe internal electron behavior even at extreme temperatures. This hidden mechanism, where oxygen vacancies act like shortcuts for electrons, could unlock faster AI systems [...]
titles: Ghost Highways in Memory Chips – The Secret Electron Shortcut to Lightning-Fast AI
summary: Researchers at POSTECH have made a significant discovery in the functionality of Electrochemical Random-Access Memory (ECRAM), revealing how oxygen vacancies serve as electron shortcuts. This finding, observed through a special technique that works even at extreme temperatures, has the potential to greatly enhance AI processing speeds and device efficiency.
constructiveness_reason: This story reports on a significant innovation in AI technology, providing both awareness of the technology and progress in the field. It also gives the reader a deeper understanding of how this discovery could impact AI processing speeds and device efficiency.
